title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: gnucashr supports managing multiple GnuCash books corporate structures multiple entities. BookCollection class provides consolidated reporting automatic intercompany elimination.

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
code: library(gnucashr)  # Create a collection with entity configuration config <- list(   parent = "Parent Corp",   subsidiaries = c("Sub A", "Sub B", "Sub C"),   fiscal_year_end = "12-31" )  collection <- book_collection(config)  # Add books collection$add_book("parent", "entities/parent/books.gnucash") collection$add_book("sub_a", "entities/sub-a/books.gnucash") collection$add_book("sub_b", "entities/sub-b/books.gnucash") collection$add_book("sub_c", "entities/sub-c/books.gnucash")  # Check loaded books collection$list_books()

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
code: # Get a specific book parent_gc <- collection$get_book("parent")  # Run operations on individual books parent_tb <- trial_balance(parent_gc)  # Apply a function to all books all_tb <- collection$each(function(gc) {   trial_balance(gc, as_of = Sys.Date()) })

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
code: # Generate consolidated trial balance # Automatically sums balances across all entities consolidated <- collection$consolidated_trial_balance(as_of = Sys.Date())  # With intercompany elimination disabled consolidated_raw <- collection$consolidated_trial_balance(   as_of = Sys.Date(),   eliminate_ic = FALSE )

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: gnucashr automatically identifies eliminates intercompany transactions:
code: # Define intercompany elimination rules ic_rules <- create_standard_ic_rules(   # Parent's receivable from Sub A   list(     parent_account = "Assets:Due from Sub A",     sub_account = "Liabilities:Due to Parent",     entity_pair = c("parent", "sub_a")   ),   # Management fees   list(     parent_account = "Income:Management Fees",     sub_account = "Expenses:Management Fees",     entity_pair = c("parent", "sub_a")   ) )  # Apply custom rules collection$set_ic_rules(ic_rules)  # Generate consolidated with eliminations consolidated <- collection$consolidated_trial_balance(   as_of = Sys.Date(),   eliminate_ic = TRUE )  # View elimination entries eliminations <- collection$ic_elimination_journal()

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
code: # Find potential intercompany transactions not being eliminated uneliminated <- identify_uneliminated_ic(collection)  # Review and add rules as needed if (nrow(uneliminated) > 0) {   print(uneliminated)   # Suggests counterparty accounts that may need elimination rules }

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
code: # Consolidated balance sheet bs <- collection$consolidated_balance_sheet(as_of = Sys.Date())  # Shows combined assets, liabilities, equity # Intercompany balances automatically eliminated  # Consolidated income statement is <- collection$consolidated_income_statement(   start_date = as.Date("2024-01-01"),   end_date = as.Date("2024-12-31") )  # Intercompany revenue/expense eliminated

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: Compare metrics across entities:
code: # Compare total assets plot_entity_comparison(   collection,   metric = "balance",   as_of = Sys.Date(),   title = "Assets by Entity" )  # Compare income plot_entity_comparison(   collection,   metric = "income",   as_of = Sys.Date(),   title = "Revenue by Entity" )  # Compare expenses plot_entity_comparison(   collection,   metric = "expense",   as_of = Sys.Date(),   title = "Expenses by Entity" )

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: Get high-level overview consolidation:
code: summary <- consolidation_summary(collection, as_of = Sys.Date())  # Returns: # - Total entities # - Combined totals (pre-elimination) # - Elimination amounts # - Consolidated totals (post-elimination) # - Intercompany balance check

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: Validate consolidation common issues:
code: # Check for issues validation <- validate_consolidation(collection)  # Reports: # - Unbalanced intercompany accounts # - Missing elimination rules # - Currency mismatches # - Fiscal year misalignment  if (!validation$is_valid) {   print(validation$issues) }

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: Use Logger monad audit trails:
code: # Wrap consolidation with logging result <- audited_consolidation(collection, as_of = Sys.Date())  # Get the data consolidated <- logged_value(result)  # Get the audit trail audit_log <- logged_log(result) print(audit_log)  # Write audit to file write_audit_log(result, "consolidation-audit.txt")

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: interactive dashboards:
code: # In a Quarto document with Shiny runtime library(shiny)  # Reactive collection paths <- reactive({   list(     parent = input$parent_file,     sub_a = input$sub_a_file,     sub_b = input$sub_b_file   ) })  rc <- reactive_book_collection(paths)  # Reactive consolidated trial balance consolidated_tb <- reactive_consolidated_tb(   rc,   reactive(input$as_of_date),   eliminate_ic = TRUE )  # Use in output output$consolidated_table <- render_gt({   gt_trial_balance(consolidated_tb()) })

title: Multi-Book Consolidation
text: Consistent Chart Accounts: Use account structure across entities accurate consolidation. Clear IC Account Naming: Name intercompany accounts clearly (e.g., “Due Sub ”, “Due Parent”). Regular Reconciliation: Run identify_uneliminated_ic() periodically catch new intercompany transactions. Audit Trails: Use audited_consolidation() formal reporting. Validation: Always run validate_consolidation() publishing reports.

title: Financial Forecasting
text: gnucashr provides lazy forecasting system builds computation pipelines without executing call collect(). enables efficient scenario comparison, Monte Carlo simulation, sensitivity analysis.

title: Financial Forecasting
code: library(gnucashr)  # Define entity configuration config <- list(   entities = list(     corp = list(       revenue = 100000,       operating_rate = 0.70,       cogs_rate = 0.25,       growth_rate = 0.05     )   ) )  # Build a lazy forecast - NO computation yet forecast <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.05, months = 12)  # Inspect the plan without executing forecast$show_plan() # <LazyForecast Plan> # Source: config # Operations: #   1. grow (rate=5.00%, months=12) # Materialized: FALSE  # Execute the forecast result <- lf_collect(forecast)

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Forecasts can built multiple sources:
code: # From entity configuration f1 <- forecast_expr(config)  # From a GnuCash book gc <- read_gnucash("books.gnucash") f2 <- from_book(gc)  # From a book collection collection <- book_collection() collection$add_book("corp", "corp.gnucash") f3 <- from_collection(collection)  # From raw data data <- tibble::tibble(   entity = "corp",   revenue = 100000,   expenses = 70000 ) f4 <- from_data(data)

title: Financial Forecasting
code: # Simple growth projection result <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.05, months = 12) |>   lf_collect()  # View projections result$projections  # Compound vs simple growth compound <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.05, months = 12, compound = TRUE) |>   lf_collect()  simple <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.05, months = 12, compound = FALSE) |>   lf_collect()

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Compare multiple scenarios without duplicating computation:
code: # Define scenarios base <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.05, months = 12)  optimistic <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.08, months = 12)  pessimistic <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.02, months = 12)  # Compare scenarios comparison <- compare_forecasts(   base = base,   optimistic = optimistic,   pessimistic = pessimistic )  # Access results comparison$base$cumulative_revenue comparison$optimistic$cumulative_revenue comparison$pessimistic$cumulative_revenue

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Run thousands simulations uncertain parameters:
code: # Build Monte Carlo forecast mc_forecast <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_monte_carlo(     n = 10000,     params = list(       growth = list(mean = 0.05, sd = 0.03),       expense = list(mean = 0.70, sd = 0.05)     ),     seed = 42   )  # Execute (uses parallel Rcpp backend) mc_result <- lf_collect(mc_forecast)  # Summary statistics mc_result$summary # Returns quantiles: p5, p25, p50, p75, p95  # Extract specific quantile median_outcome <- extract_quantile(mc_result, 0.50) worst_case <- extract_quantile(mc_result, 0.05) best_case <- extract_quantile(mc_result, 0.95)  # Visualize plot_monte_carlo(mc_result, title = "12-Month Cash Flow Projection")

title: Financial Forecasting
text: simple cases without building full pipeline:
code: # Quick Monte Carlo from config result <- quick_monte_carlo(   config,   n_sims = 10000,   n_periods = 12,   growth_mean = 0.05,   growth_sd = 0.03,   seed = 42 )  # Returns same structure as lf_monte_carlo

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Analyze outcomes change different parameters:
code: # Build sensitivity analysis sens_forecast <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_sensitivity(     growth_range = seq(-0.02, 0.10, 0.01),     expense_range = seq(0.60, 0.80, 0.02)   )  # Execute (uses parallel Rcpp backend) sens_result <- lf_collect(sens_forecast)  # Access outcomes matrix sens_result$outcomes  # growth × expense matrix  # Visualize as heatmap plot_sensitivity(sens_result, title = "Sensitivity to Growth and Expense Rates")

title: Financial Forecasting
code: # Quick sensitivity from config result <- quick_sensitivity(   config,   growth_range = seq(-0.02, 0.10, 0.01),   expense_range = seq(0.60, 0.80, 0.02),   n_periods = 12 )

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Forecast across multiple entities:
code: # Configuration with multiple entities multi_config <- list(   entities = list(     products = list(revenue = 50000, growth_rate = 0.05, operating_rate = 0.65),     services = list(revenue = 70000, growth_rate = 0.08, operating_rate = 0.60),     software = list(revenue = 7000, growth_rate = 0.05, operating_rate = 0.30)   ) )  # Forecast all entities result <- forecast_expr(multi_config) |>   lf_grow(rate = "growth_rate", months = 12) |>   lf_collect()  # Results by entity result$projections$products result$projections$services result$projections$software  # Monte Carlo across all entities mc_result <- monte_carlo_multi_entity(   multi_config,   n_sims = 10000,   n_periods = 12,   params = list(     growth_sd = 0.03,     expense_sd = 0.05   ) )

title: Financial Forecasting
text: gnucashr uses RcppParallel high-performance simulations:
code: # Parallel Monte Carlo (default) mc_result <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_monte_carlo(n = 10000, params = params) |>   lf_collect(parallel = TRUE)  # Sequential execution (for debugging) mc_result <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_monte_carlo(n = 10000, params = params) |>   lf_collect(parallel = FALSE)  # Parallel scenario projection scenarios <- parallel_project_scenarios(   base_revenue = c(50000, 70000, 7000),  # By entity   growth_matrix = matrix(     c(0.03, 0.05, 0.08),  # Low, base, high     nrow = 3, ncol = 3, byrow = TRUE   ),   n_periods = 12 )

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Track forecast operations audit logging:
code: # Create audited forecast forecast <- forecast_expr(config) |>   lf_grow(rate = 0.05, months = 12)  # Collect with audit trail result <- audited_forecast(forecast, "Q1 2025 Base Case") result <- audited_collect(result)  # Get data and log data <- logged_value(result) log <- logged_log(result)  # Write audit trail write_forecast_audit(result, "forecast-audit.txt")

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Use Result monad safe operations:
code: # Safe Monte Carlo result <- safe_quick_monte_carlo(config, n_sims = 10000)  result_match(result,   ok_fn = function(data) {     message("Median outcome: ", format_currency(data$summary$p50))   },   err_fn = function(e) {     warning("Simulation failed: ", e)   } )  # Safe sensitivity result <- safe_quick_sensitivity(config) if (is_ok(result)) {   plot_sensitivity(unwrap(result)) }

title: Financial Forecasting
code: library(shiny)  # Reactive configuration config_reactive <- reactive({   list(     entities = list(       corp = list(         revenue = input$revenue,         growth_rate = input$growth,         operating_rate = input$operating       )     )   ) })  # Reactive forecast forecast_result <- reactive_forecast(   config_reactive,   reactive(input$growth_rate),   months = 12 )  # Reactive Monte Carlo mc_result <- reactive_monte_carlo(   config_reactive,   n_sims = 10000,   reactive(input$growth_mean),   reactive(input$growth_sd) )  # Use in outputs output$forecast_plot <- renderPlot({   plot_monte_carlo(mc_result()) })

title: Financial Forecasting
text: gnucashr achieves significant speedups RcppParallel:

title: Financial Forecasting
text: Build Lazy, Execute : Compose forecast pipeline, call lf_collect() need results. Use Deterministic Seeds: Always set seed reproducible Monte Carlo results. Parallel Default: Leave parallel = TRUE production; use parallel = FALSE debugging. Audit Important Forecasts: Use audited_forecast() projections shared used decisions. Validate Inputs: Use validate_forecast_params() running expensive simulations.

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
text: gnucashr provides comprehensive R interface reading, analyzing, modeling GnuCash accounting data. vignette covers basics connecting GnuCash files performing common financial analyses.

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
text: gnucashr supports SQLite (.gnucash) XML formats:
code: library(gnucashr)  # Open a GnuCash SQLite file gc <- read_gnucash("path/to/books.gnucash")  # For XML files (compressed or uncompressed) gc_xml <- read_gnucash("path/to/books.gnucash.xml")  # Check the format gc$format

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
code: # Get all accounts as a tibble accounts <- gc$accounts() head(accounts)  # View account hierarchy tree <- account_tree(gc) print(tree)  # Get a specific account by path checking <- gc$get_account("Assets:Current:Checking")  # Get account balance bal <- account_balance(gc, "Assets:Current:Checking")

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
code: # Get all transactions txns <- gc$transactions()  # Get transactions for a specific account checking_txns <- account_transactions(gc, "Assets:Current:Checking")  # Filter by date range recent <- account_transactions(   gc,   "Assets:Current:Checking",   start = as.Date("2024-01-01"),   end = as.Date("2024-12-31") )  # Calculate running balance with_balance <- calculate_running_balance(recent)

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
code: # Generate trial balance tb <- trial_balance(gc, as_of = Sys.Date()) print(tb)  # Format as gt table for display library(gt) gt_trial_balance(tb, title = "Trial Balance - Q4 2024")

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
code: # Generate balance sheet bs <- balance_sheet(gc, as_of = Sys.Date())  # Access sections bs$assets bs$liabilities bs$equity  # Verify accounting equation bs$total_assets == bs$total_liabilities + bs$total_equity  # Format for display gt_balance_sheet(bs, title = "Balance Sheet")

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
code: # Generate income statement for a period is <- income_statement(   gc,   start_date = as.Date("2024-01-01"),   end_date = as.Date("2024-12-31") )  # Access sections is$income is$expenses is$net_income  # Format for display gt_income_statement(is, title = "2024 Income Statement")

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
code: # Get monthly activity for an account activity <- monthly_activity(gc, "Expenses:Operating")  # Plot the trend library(ggplot2) plot_monthly_activity(activity, title = "Monthly Operating Expenses")

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
text: Quarto dashboards, use dashboard_metrics() function:
code: # Get key metrics for value boxes metrics <- dashboard_metrics(gc, as_of = Sys.Date())  # Available metrics: # - total_assets # - total_liabilities # - net_worth # - total_income # - total_expenses # - net_income # - account_count # - transaction_count  # Format for display format_currency(metrics$net_worth)

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
text: gnucashr uses Result monad error handling:
code: # Safe file reading result <- safe_read_gnucash("maybe-missing.gnucash")  # Check result if (is_ok(result)) {   gc <- unwrap(result)   message("Loaded successfully!") } else {   error <- unwrap_err(result)   warning("Failed to load: ", error) }  # Pattern matching result_match(result,   ok_fn = function(gc) {     message("Accounts: ", nrow(gc$accounts()))   },   err_fn = function(e) {     warning("Error: ", e)   } )

title: Getting Started with gnucashr
text: Always close connections done:
code: # Close explicitly gc$close()  # Or use with() for automatic cleanup with_gnucash("books.gnucash", function(gc) {   trial_balance(gc) })

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: gnucashr provides standardized importers common payment platforms accounting systems. importers convert platform-specific CSV exports common format can easily analyzed imported GnuCash. Currently supported platforms: PayPal - Activity download exports Stripe - Balance transaction exports QuickBooks - Online (QBO) Desktop CSV exports

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
code: library(gnucashr)  # Import from PayPal paypal_data <- import_paypal_csv("paypal_activity.csv")  # Import from Stripe stripe_data <- import_stripe_csv("stripe_balance.csv")  # Import from QuickBooks qb_data <- import_quickbooks_csv("quickbooks_export.csv")  # Combine multiple sources all_transactions <- combine_csv_imports(paypal_data, stripe_data, qb_data)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: importers return tibble gnucashr_csv_import class containing standardized columns: importers include additional columns like fee transaction fees.

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Log PayPal Business Personal account Go Activity > Transactions Click “Download” select CSV format Choose date range

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: PayPal exports vary slightly depending account type region. gnucashr auto-detects format maps columns:

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
code: # Basic import paypal <- import_paypal_csv("paypal_activity.csv")  # Include pending transactions (excluded by default) paypal_all <- import_paypal_csv("paypal_activity.csv", include_pending = TRUE)  # Specify timezone for date conversion paypal_pst <- import_paypal_csv("paypal_activity.csv", timezone = "America/Los_Angeles")  # View results print(paypal) head(paypal)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: category column classifies transactions: payment - Received payments refund - Refunds issued fee - PayPal fees transfer - Bank transfers withdrawals conversion - Currency conversions hold - Temporary holds reversal - Payment reversals - transaction types

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Log Stripe Dashboard Go Balance > Balance history Click “Export” select CSV Choose columns date range

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
code: # Basic import stripe <- import_stripe_csv("stripe_balance.csv")  # Include fee breakdown (default is TRUE) stripe <- import_stripe_csv("stripe_balance.csv", include_fees = TRUE)  # Specify timezone stripe <- import_stripe_csv("stripe_balance.csv", timezone = "UTC")  print(stripe)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Stripe exports amounts smallest currency unit (cents USD). importer automatically detects converts standard decimal format: 10000 (cents) becomes 100.00 (dollars) -2500 (cents) becomes -25.00 (dollars)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: charge - Customer charges/payments refund - Refunds customers payout - Payouts bank account fee - Stripe fees adjustment - Balance adjustments dispute - Chargebacks disputes - transaction types

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: QuickBooks Online: 1. Go Reports > Transaction List Date 2. Customize date range columns 3. Export CSV QuickBooks Desktop: 1. Go Reports > Accountant & Taxes > Transaction List Date 2. Set date range 3. Export Excel/CSV

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: gnucashr automatically detects whether export : QBO format - QuickBooks Online (“Transaction Type” column) Desktop format - QuickBooks Desktop (separate Debit/Credit columns)
code: # Auto-detect format qb <- import_quickbooks_csv("qb_export.csv")  # Force specific format qb_online <- import_quickbooks_csv("qb_export.csv", format = "qbo") qb_desktop <- import_quickbooks_csv("qb_export.csv", format = "desktop")  print(qb)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: invoice - Customer invoices payment - Received payments expense - Bills expenses check - Check payments transfer - Account transfers journal - Journal entries deposit - Bank deposits refund - Customer refunds sale - Sales transactions - transaction types

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Use combine_csv_imports() merge transactions multiple sources:
code: # Import from multiple sources paypal <- import_paypal_csv("paypal.csv") stripe <- import_stripe_csv("stripe.csv") qb <- import_quickbooks_csv("quickbooks.csv")  # Combine all all_data <- combine_csv_imports(paypal, stripe, qb)  # With duplicate detection all_data <- combine_csv_imports(   paypal, stripe, qb,   deduplicate = TRUE,   dedupe_key = c("date", "amount", "description") )  # View combined data print(all_data) nrow(all_data)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: importing multiple sources, may duplicate transactions (e.g., PayPal payment also appears QuickBooks). Use deduplicate option:
code: # Deduplicate by date, amount, and description combined <- combine_csv_imports(   paypal, stripe,   deduplicate = TRUE,   dedupe_key = c("date", "amount", "description") )  # Custom deduplication key combined <- combine_csv_imports(   paypal, stripe,   deduplicate = TRUE,   dedupe_key = c("date", "amount")  # Less strict matching )

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Imports preserve currency information source:
code: # Check currencies in import unique(paypal$currency)  # Filter by currency usd_only <- paypal |>   dplyr::filter(currency == "USD")  # Group by currency paypal |>   dplyr::group_by(currency) |>   dplyr::summarise(     count = dplyr::n(),     total = sum(amount)   )

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Use validate_csv_import() check common issues:
code: # Check for issues validation <- validate_csv_import(paypal)  if (!validation$valid) {   print(validation$issues) }  # Strict mode throws error on issues validate_csv_import(paypal, strict = TRUE)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: Use preview_csv_mapping() debug import issues: shows: - Detected format - Column names file - column maps standard format - Sample values first rows
code: # See how columns will be mapped before importing preview_csv_mapping("paypal.csv", import_paypal_csv)

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: imported, use standard dplyr operations:
code: library(dplyr)  # Filter by date range recent <- paypal |>   filter(date >= as.Date("2024-01-01"))  # Summarize by category paypal |>   group_by(category) |>   summarise(     count = n(),     total = sum(amount),     avg = mean(amount)   )  # Monthly totals paypal |>   mutate(month = lubridate::floor_date(date, "month")) |>   group_by(month) |>   summarise(total = sum(amount))  # Find large transactions paypal |>   filter(abs(amount) > 1000) |>   arrange(desc(abs(amount)))

title: Importing Data from Payment Platforms
text: importing data, can: Create GnuCash transactions using create_transaction() Generate financial reports trial_balance() income_statement() Perform cash flow analysis forecasting tools See Getting Started vignette working GnuCash data R.

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: GnuCash stores monetary values fractions (numerator/denominator) avoid floating-point rounding errors. Converting doubles hot path balance calculations.

title: Performance Benchmarks
code: # Pure R version for comparison fraction_to_double_r <- function(numerator, denominator) {   ifelse(     is.na(numerator) | is.na(denominator) | denominator == 0,     NA_real_,     numerator / denominator   ) }

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Typical Results: Speedup: ~5.6x half memory allocation.
code: # Generate test data n <- 1e6 num <- sample(1:10000, n, replace = TRUE) denom <- sample(c(1, 10, 100, 1000), n, replace = TRUE)  results <- bench::mark(   r_version = fraction_to_double_r(num, denom),   rcpp_version = fraction_to_double(num, denom),   check = FALSE,   min_iterations = 10 )  print(results)

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Adding fractions maintaining exact representation (accumulating balances without drift):
code: # Test data: pairs of fractions n <- 100000 num1 <- sample(1:1000, n, replace = TRUE) denom1 <- rep(100L, n) num2 <- sample(1:1000, n, replace = TRUE) denom2 <- rep(100L, n)  results <- bench::mark(   rcpp_version = add_fractions(num1, denom1, num2, denom2),   min_iterations = 10 )

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Monte Carlo simulation benefits parallelization. gnucashr uses RcppParallel thread-safe parallel execution.

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Typical Results: Speedup: ~62x
code: config <- list(   entities = list(     corp = list(       revenue = 100000,       operating_rate = 0.70,       growth_rate = 0.05     )   ) )  results <- bench::mark(   parallel = monte_carlo_parallel(     base_revenue = 100000,     base_expense_rate = 0.70,     n_sims = 10000,     n_periods = 12,     seed = 42   ),   sequential = {     # Pure R version for comparison     set.seed(42)     replicate(10000, {       revenue <- 100000       cumulative <- 0       for (p in 1:12) {         growth <- rnorm(1, 0.05, 0.03)         expense <- rnorm(1, 0.70, 0.05)         revenue <- revenue * (1 + growth)         net <- revenue * (1 - expense)         cumulative <- cumulative + net       }       cumulative     })   },   check = FALSE,   min_iterations = 5 )  print(results)

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Typical Results: throughput remains consistent approximately 220,000-230,000 simulations per second, indicating excellent parallel scaling.
code: sim_counts <- c(1000, 5000, 10000, 50000, 100000)  scaling_results <- lapply(sim_counts, function(n) {   time <- bench::mark(     monte_carlo_parallel(       base_revenue = 100000,       base_expense_rate = 0.70,       n_sims = n,       n_periods = 12,       seed = 42     ),     min_iterations = 3   )$median    data.frame(n_sims = n, time_ms = as.numeric(time) * 1000) })  scaling_df <- do.call(rbind, scaling_results) print(scaling_df)

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Parallel sensitivity analysis computes outcomes across grid parameter combinations.

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: Typical Results: Speedup: ~10x
code: growth_range <- seq(-0.02, 0.10, by = 0.01)  # 13 values expense_range <- seq(0.60, 0.80, by = 0.02)  # 11 values  results <- bench::mark(   parallel = parallel_sensitivity_grid(     base_revenue = 100000,     base_expense_rate = 0.70,     growth_range = growth_range,     expense_range = expense_range,     n_periods = 12   ),   sequential = {     # Pure R version     sapply(growth_range, function(g) {       sapply(expense_range, function(e) {         rev <- 100000         cum <- 0         for (p in 1:12) {           rev <- rev * (1 + g)           cum <- cum + rev * (1 - e)         }         cum       })     })   },   check = FALSE,   min_iterations = 10 )  print(results)

title: Performance Benchmarks
code: # Larger grids show more dramatic speedups grid_sizes <- list(   small = list(growth = 10, expense = 10),    # 100 scenarios   medium = list(growth = 25, expense = 20),   # 500 scenarios   large = list(growth = 50, expense = 40),    # 2000 scenarios   xlarge = list(growth = 100, expense = 100)  # 10000 scenarios )  grid_results <- lapply(names(grid_sizes), function(name) {   g <- grid_sizes[[name]]   time <- bench::mark(     parallel_sensitivity_grid(       base_revenue = 100000,       base_expense_rate = 0.70,       growth_range = seq(0, 0.1, length.out = g$growth),       expense_range = seq(0.5, 0.9, length.out = g$expense),       n_periods = 12     ),     min_iterations = 5   )$median    data.frame(     grid = name,     scenarios = g$growth * g$expense,     time_ms = as.numeric(time) * 1000   ) })  grid_df <- do.call(rbind, grid_results) print(grid_df)

code: # Generate test transactions (balanced splits) n_txns <- 10000 splits_per_txn <- 4  # Create balanced split sets create_balanced_splits <- function(n_splits) {   values <- sample(100:10000, n_splits - 1)   c(values, -sum(values)) }  all_nums <- unlist(lapply(1:n_txns, function(i) create_balanced_splits(splits_per_txn))) all_denoms <- rep(100L, length(all_nums))  # Validate all splits (vectorized across entire dataset) results <- bench::mark(   rcpp_version = validate_splits_balance(all_nums, all_denoms),   min_iterations = 20 )  print(results)

code: # Large dataset memory comparison n <- 1e7 num <- sample(1:10000, n, replace = TRUE) denom <- sample(c(1, 10, 100, 1000), n, replace = TRUE)  # R version creates intermediate vectors r_mem <- bench::mark(   fraction_to_double_r(num, denom),   iterations = 1 )$mem_alloc  # Rcpp version works in-place rcpp_mem <- bench::mark(   fraction_to_double(num, denom),   iterations = 1 )$mem_alloc  cat("R memory allocation:", format(r_mem), "\n") cat("Rcpp memory allocation:", format(rcpp_mem), "\n")

title: Performance Benchmarks
text: typical financial analysis workflow combining multiple operations: Typical Result: Complete workflow ~60ms
code: # Simulated workflow: load, analyze, forecast workflow_benchmark <- function() {   # 1. Generate trial balance data (simulating account balances)   accounts <- data.frame(     account = paste0("Account_", 1:1000),     num = sample(-100000:100000, 1000, replace = TRUE),     denom = rep(100L, 1000)   )    # 2. Convert fractions to doubles   balances <- fraction_to_double(accounts$num, accounts$denom)    # 3. Run Monte Carlo projection   mc <- monte_carlo_parallel(     base_revenue = sum(balances[balances > 0]),     base_expense_rate = abs(sum(balances[balances < 0])) /                         sum(balances[balances > 0]),     n_sims = 10000,     n_periods = 12   )    # 4. Run sensitivity analysis   sens <- parallel_sensitivity_grid(     base_revenue = sum(balances[balances > 0]),     base_expense_rate = 0.70,     growth_range = seq(-0.02, 0.10, by = 0.01),     expense_range = seq(0.60, 0.80, by = 0.02),     n_periods = 12   )    list(mc = mc, sens = sens) }  results <- bench::mark(   workflow_benchmark(),   min_iterations = 5 )  print(results)

title: Rcpp Internals
text: GnuCash stores monetary values fractions avoid floating-point errors. functions provide vectorized conversion exact arithmetic.

title: Rcpp Internals
code: // Greatest common divisor (Euclidean algorithm) int64_t gcd(int64_t a, int64_t b);  // Least common multiple int64_t lcm(int64_t a, int64_t b);

title: Rcpp Internals
text: fraction_to_double(numerator, denominator) Converts GnuCash fraction representation double. hot path balance calculations. Key implementation details: NA propagation missing values Zero denominator returns NA (Inf) Static cast double division avoid integer overflow add_fractions(num1, denom1, num2, denom2) Adds fractions using exact integer arithmetic LCM-based common denominator. Returns reduced fractions.
code: // [[Rcpp::export]] NumericVector fraction_to_double(IntegerVector numerator,                                   IntegerVector denominator) {     int n = numerator.size();     NumericVector result(n);      for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {         if (IntegerVector::is_na(numerator[i]) ||             IntegerVector::is_na(denominator[i]) ||             denominator[i] == 0) {             result[i] = NA_REAL;         } else {             result[i] = static_cast<double>(numerator[i]) /                         static_cast<double>(denominator[i]);         }     }     return result; } // Find common denominator int64_t common = lcm(d1, d2);  // Scale numerators int64_t n1 = num1[i] * (common / d1); int64_t n2 = num2[i] * (common / d2);  // Add and reduce int64_t sum = n1 + n2; int64_t g = gcd(sum, common); result_num = sum / g; result_denom = common / g;

title: Rcpp Internals
text: GnuCash uses 32-character lowercase hex GUIDs without dashes.

title: Rcpp Internals
text: Uses thread-local random engine safe concurrent generation: thread_local keyword ensures thread gets RNG instance, preventing data races parallel code.
code: std::mt19937& get_random_engine() {     static thread_local std::mt19937 engine(std::random_device{}());     return engine; }

title: Rcpp Internals
code: // [[Rcpp::export]] String generate_guid() {     std::mt19937& engine = get_random_engine();     std::uniform_int_distribution<int> dist(0, 15);      std::stringstream ss;     ss << std::hex << std::setfill('0');      for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) {         ss << dist(engine);     }      return ss.str(); }

code: // [[Rcpp::depends(RcppParallel)]] #include <RcppParallel.h>  struct MonteCarloWorker : public Worker {     // Input parameters (const references)     const double base_revenue;     // ... other parameters      // Output matrices (RMatrix/RVector for thread-safe access)     RMatrix<double> results;     RVector<double> final_cash;      // Constructor     MonteCarloWorker(...) : ... {}      // Worker function called for each grain     void operator()(std::size_t begin, std::size_t end) {         // Thread-local RNG with deterministic seed         std::mt19937_64 rng(master_seed + begin);          for (std::size_t sim = begin; sim < end; ++sim) {             // Perform simulation         }     } };

title: Rcpp Internals
text: Projects multiple growth scenarios across entities:
code: struct ScenarioProjectionWorker : public Worker {     const RVector<double> base_values;     const RMatrix<double> growth_matrix;  // scenarios x entities     const int n_periods;      RMatrix<double> results;  // scenarios x (entities * periods)     RVector<double> final_totals;      void operator()(std::size_t begin, std::size_t end) {         for (std::size_t scenario = begin; scenario < end; ++scenario) {             for (int entity = 0; entity < n_entities; ++entity) {                 // Project growth for this scenario/entity combination             }         }     } };

title: Rcpp Internals
text: Computes outcomes across 2D parameter grid: linear--2D index conversion allows parallel iteration grid.
code: struct SensitivityGridWorker : public Worker {     const RVector<double> growth_range;     const RVector<double> expense_range;      RMatrix<double> outcomes;  // growth x expense      void operator()(std::size_t begin, std::size_t end) {         for (std::size_t idx = begin; idx < end; ++idx) {             // Convert linear index to 2D grid coordinates             int g_idx = idx / n_expense;             int e_idx = idx % n_expense;              // Compute outcome for this parameter combination         }     } };

title: Rcpp Internals
text: Transaction validation uses exact integer arithmetic verify double-entry balance.

title: Rcpp Internals
text: Key points: Uses int64_t avoid overflow large denominators LCM-based scaling provides exact arithmetic Optional tolerance floating-point imports
code: // [[Rcpp::export]] List validate_transaction_balance(IntegerVector value_nums,                                    IntegerVector value_denoms,                                    double tolerance = 0.0) {     // 1. Find LCM of all denominators     int64_t lcm = 1;     for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {         // Compute running LCM     }      // 2. Sum all values scaled to common denominator     int64_t total = 0;     for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {         total += value_nums[i] * (lcm / value_denoms[i]);     }      // 3. Check balance (exact or within tolerance)     bool balanced = (total == 0) ||                     (std::abs(total_decimal) <= tolerance);      return List::create(...); }
